items.title: #002 — Beware the Riboflavin Lobby
items.content_html: Some will say that this second episode of Flux Observer should have been the first. In it I provide exciting details, such as my name, and where you can find my various projects on the internet. There’s also some talk about vitamins, and half German-language Shakespeare puns (sorta), but that’s all superfluous — it’s mostly novelty domain names all the way down.

items.title: How to Steal a Million dir. William Wyler (1966) ★★★★
items.content_html:
I am too infrequently asked to name my favourite Audrey Hepburn movie, but if I were, most days I would probably say Roman Holiday (1953). And yet I had not seen William Wyler’s other light-hearted caper team-up with Hepburn until now.

I could probably watch Audrey drive around Paris in her ridiculous little toy car, wearing Givenchy outfits, for hours beyond the film’s actual running time.

“Where precisely were you in the early part of the sixteenth century?”
“I don’t know, but that’s not how I was dressed.”

I am also yet to see The Children’s Hour (1961), but — as a Lillian Hellman adaptation — that looks to be a different prospect.

🍿
items.content_text:
I am too infrequently asked to name my favourite Audrey Hepburn movie, but if I were, most days I would probably say *Roman Holiday* (1953). And yet I had not seen William Wyler's other light-hearted caper team-up with Hepburn until now. 

I could probably watch Audrey drive around Paris in her ridiculous little toy car, wearing Givenchy outfits, for hours beyond the film’s actual running time.

> “Where precisely were you in the early part of the sixteenth century?”  
“I don't know, but that's not how I was dressed.”

I am also yet to see *The Children’s Hour* (1961), but — as a Lillian Hellman adaptation — that looks to be a different prospect.

🍿

items.content_html:
We spent the afternoon at Harcourt Arboretum. It’s a joy to visit with some of these amazing trees, including Corsican Pine, Western Yellow Pine, Blue Cedar, & Coastal Redwoods.

Here’s a photo of one of my favourites this time around, with its upturned leaves: Shirasawa’s Maple.

Here’s a photo of one of my favourites this time around, with its upturned leaves: Shirasawa’s Maple.

I’m going to take a run at posting a photo for each of 30 straight days, and — as a way of needlessly complicating things for myself — I’m going to structure it as 3 pictures from each year: 2012-21.

I’ll try to add a little context where it’s useful. Let’s see how we get on.

items.title: #001 — A New Mantra
items.content_html: Within the first ten words of this debut episode of Flux Observer, I make a mistake: I call something a mantra, when it’s really more of an aphorism. But that’s OK, because this whole thing is an experiment, and it’s allowed to be a mess. What’s more, this episode is specifically about letting go of the idea of perfectibility.
items.content_text:
Within the first ten words of this debut episode of *Flux Observer*, I make a mistake: I call something a mantra, when it's really more of an aphorism. But that's OK, because this whole thing is an experiment, and it’s allowed to be a mess. What's more, this episode is specifically about letting go of the idea of perfectibility.
